result.execSummary:
The defendant Harlon W Raymond Jr was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Armed Robbery with Threat of Force [Modifiers: Repeater, PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class C felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.32(2).
  • Felon Possess Firearm [Modifiers: Repeater, PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class G felony, Wisconsin Statutes 941.29(2)(a).
  • Criminal Damage to Property [Modifiers: PTAC, as a Party to a Crime, Repeater, Use of a Dangerous Weapon], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.01(1).
  • Resisting or Obstructing an Officer [Modifiers: Repeater, Use of a Dangerous Weapon, PTAC, as a Party to a Crime], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 946.41(1).
  • Criminal Trespass to Dwelling [Modifiers: Repeater], a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 943.14.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

parties.name: Portage County Clerk of Circuit Court

supervisions.notes: Consecutive to: Consecutive to any other sentences currently being served.

superMiscConds.notes:
Pay restitution in the amount of $538.00.  Joint/several with co-defendants.
25% of all moneys deposited into the defendants prison account shall be applied to the payment of fines, costs & restitution in this file.  If any fines, costs & restitution remain outstanding at the end of the confinement portion of this sentence, then the remaining balances shall be paid as a condition of extended supervision.

Pay costs including the DNA surcharge.
If probation is discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 25% of gross.

No contact with co-defendants. 
No contact with victims unless written approval given to agent from victims.

Completion of cognitive based intervention programming or other programming as deemed necessary by the agent. 
Set up payment plan with agent to pay back any restitution and ordered court costs to include the DNA surcharge. 
Pay supervision fees as directed by the Department of Corrections.

records.addlTxt: Waiver of Preliminary Hearing/Arraignment/Plea (15CF225)/Sentencing held on August 31, 2015
Records request from State Public Defender dated 02/12/16 - per clerk MH mailed on 02/18/16
from DOC re: jail credit
Jail credit stands

Defendant Harlon W Raymond in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. Defendant Harlon W Raymond in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

1:35 p.m  Court calls case.
Atty Molepske states the appearances.
State has complied with the victim notification in this case.

Court and counsel have received their copies of the PSI (the original and amended)
Court questions if any correction need to be made on the record.
Atty Molepske does not have any corrections to the PSI.
Atty Kryshak does not have any corrections to the PSI.
Victim notification complied with; letter had been received by the Court and provided to all parties.
Cheryl Clinton makes statement to the Court.
No other victim's in the courtroom to make a statement.
Prosecutor argues regarding sentencing.
Court is not able to locate the restitution summary.
Atty Kryshak stipulates that the restitution is $1,938.00.
Attorney for Defendant argues regarding sentencing.
Atty Kryshak indicates that his client was on supervision at the time of the crime and has 95 days jail credit until he was revoked.
Defendant makes a statement prior to his sentencing.

BY THE COURT:
Count 8 -
15 years prison with 5 years initial confinement and 10 years extended supervision to run consecutive to any other sentences currently being served 
Conditions of extended supervision as outlined in PSI on page 22:
*Obtain/Maintain full-time employment
*No contact with co-defendants
*No contact with victims unless written approval given to Agent from victims
*Completion of congitive based intervention programming or other programming as deemed necessary by the Agent
*Set up payment plan with Agent to pay back any restitution and ordered Court costs (to include DNA surcharge)
*Pay supervision fees as directed by the Department of Corrections
*95 days jail credit
*25% of monies in prison account to be applied to costs
*Pay restitution in the amount of $538 joint/several with co-defendants
*Not eligible for the Challenge Incarceration Program or Substance Abuse Program 
 
Count 9 -
6 years prison with 3 years initial confinement and 3 years extended supervision to run concurrent to Count 8 but consecutive to any other sentences currently being served

Count 10 -
364 days county jail to run conccurrent to each other and concurrent to Counts 8 & 9

Count 11 - DRI
Count 12 - DRI
Count 13 - DRI

Count 14 -
364 days county jail to run conccurrent to each other and concurrent to Counts 8 & 9
Count 15 -
364 days county jail to run conccurrent to each other and concurrent to Counts 8 & 9
Amended
from N. Chmielewski

records.addlTxt: Sentencing hearing at 08-31-2015 01:30 pm

Defendant Harlon W Raymond in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. Defendant Harlon W Raymond in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Cases heard at this time are 15CF-225 and 14CF-461.

1:34 PM Court calls cases.
Atty Molepske states appearances.

These matters are set for an initial appearance in 14CF-225 and a plea hearing in 14CF-461.

15CF-225:
Atty Kryshak received a copy of the complaint, waives reading. 
Atty Kryshak waives time for preliminary hearing and requests a signature bond.
Court informs Defendant of charges and penalties.

Court will bind this case over and set matter for a preliminary hearing.

14CF-461:
Defendant will plead to Amended Count 8, Count 9, Count 10, Count 14, and Count 15.
Count 8: State recommends a capped sentence of 10 yrs initial confinement. Parties request a PSI. Parties will be free to argue. 
Count 9: State recommends a prison sentence of 6 years, 3 yrs initial, 3 yrs extended, concurrent to Count 8
Count 10, 14 and 15: State recommends jail sentence, concurrent to each count
Restitution joint and several $1,938

Atty Kryshak concurs.
Defendant concurs.

Plea questionnaire/Agreement filed.

Defendant enters a plea of: 
NO CONTEST to Count 8, Count 9, Count 10, Count 14 and Count 15 in 14CF-461.

Court questions Defendant regarding pleas.
Court informs Defendant of Constitutional Rights. Court advises Defendant of Elements State must prove for the Charge.
Court questions Attorney Kryshakfor Defendant.
State has complied with victim notification statutes.
Court finds Defendant's Plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.
Attorneys stipulate that there is factual basis for the charges.

BY THE COURT:
Court finds a sufficient factual basis to support the charges.
Court finds the defendant guilty.  Clerk directed to enter Judgment of Conviction this date.
14CF-461:
Count 11, Count 12, Count 13: Dismissed and Read In
Count 8: Found Guilty
Count 9: Found Guilty
Count 10: Found Guilty
Count 14: Found Guilty
Count 15: Found Guilty

BY THE COURT:
Court will order a PSI.
To be completed at least one week prior to sentencing date.
Parties are to contact judicial assistant to schedule sentencing date.
Bond in 14CF-461 is REVOKED.

15CF-225: $1,000 signature bond set
Plea hearing at 06-24-2015 01:30 pm
for Discovery and/or Sanctions
Pre-trial conference at 06-08-2015 10:00 am

Defendant Harlon W Raymond in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. Louis Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
2:30 p.m.  Court calls the case. 
Atty Molepske notes Tanner Raymond is present with counsel Atty Karl Schmidt as well.  Not sure if the Court will proceed hearing both files together or if it will be separate.
Atty Kryshak makes statements.  Number of the motions are for the same for both files.  

BY THE COURT:  Court will hear the files separately. 

Notice of Intent to Use DNA Evidence: 
Atty Kryshak makes arguments to the Court.  
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
Court questions Atty Molepske.
BY THE COURT:  Motion in response will be filed by Atty Kryshak. 

Motion to Introduce Evidence of Flight:
Court concern there is no affidavit indicates what evidence it intends to use. 
Atty Kryshak makes arguments to the Court. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
Court questions Atty Molepske. 
Atty Kryshak makes additional arguments to the Court. 
Atty Molepske makes additional arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  The decision will be made at the jury instruction portion. 

Motions in Limine:
#1 - No objection.  
BY THE COURT:  All witness will be sequestered.

#2 - No objection. 
BY THE COURT:  Granted. 

#3 - Statutory. 
Atty Kryshak indicates he does not have a witness list from the State.  
Court questions Atty Molepske. 
Atty Molepske indicates the witness list will be filed within a reasonable time before trial.  There has been additional parties interviewed.  
Court notes it can be supplemented. 

#4 - Atty Kryshak indicates he agrees there is 15 convictions.  
BY THE COURT:  Granted. 

#5 - Atty Kryshak believes this is standard.  Court agrees.

#6 - 
Court questions Atty Molepske.
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court.  Seeking to introduce statements in video format. 
Atty Kryshak makes arguments to the Court.  Does not know if he has all the police reports.  Asks to be provided with a complete set of police reports. 
Atty Molepske makes statements.  Asks what reference requested by Atty Kryshak. 
BY THE COURT:  With regards to the statements, State is itemize and provide to Atty Kryshak and if the two find there is a problem, then a hearing will be held. 
There are no Miranda Goodchild objections. 
Atty Kryshak will contact the Court if there is a problem with the video. 
BY THE COURT: Transcript be provided to the defense of the video ASAP to review for accuracy and any disagreement of what it says is handled well before trial. 

#7 - 
Atty Kryshak makes statements. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  Court won't make a specific ruling but will follow the Rules of Evidence at trial. 

#8 - 
Court notes this is likely an evidentiary issue at trial. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
Atty Kryshak makes arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  Court will rule on as this comes up at trial which would require a proper foundation. 

#9 - 
Atty Kryshak makes statements to the Court. 
Atty Molepske makes statements to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  Other Acts Evidence to be brought by motion prior to trial.  Court does not make a specific ruling, this is an evidentiary rule. 

#10 - 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
Atty Kryshak makes arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  Court will be responsible for instructing the jury on the law.   Court will address the law based on the facts presented at trial. 

#12 - 
Atty Kryshak makes statements to the Court.  
BY THE COURT:  Court will rule accordingly at trial. 

#11 - 
BY THE COURT:  Court allows jurors to take notes during testimony.  Note pads are not handed out until after opening arguments.  They are not allowed to take notes at closing arguments.  Court will instruct them appropriately.

Defendant Harlon W Raymond in court with attorney Gary J. Kryshak. Defendant Harlon W Raymond in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

3:18 p.m.  Court calls case
Atty Molepske states the appearances.

Defendant waives right to Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions the Defendant regarding Waiver of Preliminary Hearing.
Court questions Defendant's attorney.
Court finds the Defendant has freely, voluntarily and intelligently waived the Preliminary Hearing.
On the defendants waiver of the preliminary hearing, Court determines, based on the facts contained in the complaint, there is sufficient probable cause and binds the defendant over for trial. 



BY THE COURT:
Bond and conditions of bond continued  State files Information.
Defendant received copy of information.
Defendant waives reading of information. 

NOT GUILTY Plea(s) entered.

Bond Continued.  Pre-trial conference scheduled for February 16, 2015 at 08:30 am.
